history.content:
Every instructor is different, but CS 70 over the summer is historically much easier than CS 70 during a semester.  And in previous offerings they managed to cover most/all of the material to the best of my knowledge.

-----------------------------

I TA'd in su14 and su15, and I followed along the course in su16.

su14 and su15 cut the Berlekamp-Welch algorithm for general errors in error-correcting codes, and a couple of topics near the end were untested. Otherwise, the bulk of the material were still there.

su16 didn't cut any topics, but possibly covered more than a regular semester (in that it covered a number of special topics that are only occasionally taught). I have no idea how they managed this; apparently they didn't realize that those topics weren't always taught.

It's hard to compare with the regular semester's difficulty, because that varies quite a bit by professor. I don't think it really gets into 2x workload of the regular semester though, not because it skips topics, but just that the homeworks aren't as long as they should be.

Every instructor is different, but CS 70 over the summer is historically much easier than CS 70 during a semester.  And in previous offerings they managed to cover most/all of the material to the best of my knowledge.

children.subject: For one, homework is still only once a week - so you have a total of ~8 homeworks compared with 14.
What makes CS 70 historically much easier during the summer if it covers all of the same material?

Well, the teaching style during the regular semester (i.e. between professors) is also quite variable; I don't think it's more so during the summer.

I think the summer version of the course is perfectly fine to take; I don't expect students to be disadvantaged because they took it during the summer. Note that the summer course is 8 weeks (and the regular semester is only 12-13 weeks or something if we exclude holidays / dead week / finals week when no new material gets covered), and the material is covered twice as quickly, so the total amount of time a student spends on the course should be about the same.

Since CS 70 is such an integral part of the CS curriculum and the teaching style/material covered is more variable over the summer, would you recommend putting off taking 70 over the summer and just taking it during the regular school year (thus spending more time on the material with 15 vs 6 weeks)?

CS 70 summer vs semester?

So I recently signed up to take CS 70 over summer and now im having second thoughts about it. I've heard people say CS 70 takes a long time to conceptually grasp the material so I wanted to take it alone over summer but then again, summer goes by very fast. Would you recommend taking it over the summer or doing it in the fall (with Kannan Ramachandran)??

Nothing about the class is really easier. At least last summer. Distributions seemed to be the same and exams were pretty difficult (our final was pretty bad). I think what makes it easier is that you only have to focus on one class.

Some people spread the idea that it's easier over the summer, but even if that is true for some people I am fairly confident it would be the opposite for others, and also it would vary from summer to summer (I heard that last summer was actually absurdly difficult), and anyway what are the chances that all of these people actually took the class twice to compare? So I wouldn't plan your schedule around this rumor.

CS 70 input

Can somebody who has taken CS 70 give input on summer vs semester? Whether it's easier or harder?? Thank you so much.

history.content:
I was planning on taking CS 70 over summer; however, I want to make sure that key parts of the curriculum are not omitted because of the time constraints placed on the course. Additionally, can anyone shed light on if taking CS70 over summer prepares you significantly less for other upper-division courses, specifically 170.

Thanks!
history.subject: Is taking CS70 over summer a good idea?
